VS Code + Tailwind treat this as a deprecated pattern.

Because newer Tailwind configs recommend putting external fonts in tailwind.config.js or using <link> tags in HTML instead of CSS @import.

How To Fix It (Best Practice)

Option A ‚Äî Keep It As-Is (Totally Works)

Option B ‚Äî Tailwind-Approved Fix (Recommended)

Remove the @import entirely and add the font via your HTML:

Add this inside <head>

<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com">
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin>
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:wght@400;500;600;700&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

Then in tailwind.config.js, set:

theme: {
  fontFamily: {
    sans: ['Inter', 'sans-serif'],

}

Introduction

The Ceremonial Infrastructure Scroll of the Evolvers is a conceptual framework that positions Afro‚Äëdiasporic genealogical truth, ceremonial restitution and sovereign economic systems as complementary pillars. 1. Afro‚Äëcentric Lineage Truth

1.1 Oral Historiography and Griots

African societies maintain genealogies and histories through griots, hereditary troubadour‚Äëhistorians.  Britannica notes that griots preserve genealogies, historical narratives and oral traditions of their people and often serve as advisers and diplomats„Äê619047801681022‚Ä†L169-L176„Äë. 1.2 Genetic Continuity

Modern genetics supports deep continuity within African populations and helps link oral histories to biological lineages.  Haplogroup E is the most common Y‚Äëchromosome clade in Africa„Äê332531598544666‚Ä†L48-L74„Äë.  One sub‚Äëclade, E1b1b (E‚ÄëM215), reaches frequencies of 40‚Äì80¬†% in Ethiopia and Somalia and occurs across North Africa, pointing to an East‚ÄëAfrican origin„Äê332531598544666‚Ä†L48-L74„Äë.  Its sister branch E1b1a (E‚ÄëM2) is the most common Y‚ÄëDNA haplogroup in West Africa (70‚Äì97¬†%) and moderately frequent in Central and southern Africa„Äê332531598544666‚Ä†L130-L133„Äë.  Genetic studies of royal Egyptian mummies identified haplogroup E1b1a in Ramesses¬†III and Pentawer, and researchers noted that this clade is most frequent today in West and Central Africa„Äê529502647457519‚Ä†L156-L170„Äë.  These findings support the Scroll‚Äôs assertion that living populations retain genetic links with ancient Nile Valley lineages.

Ethiopian talismanic scrolls provide an example of written genealogical and healing technologies. Each scroll is customised by a dabtara (unordained cleric) for a specific individual; the texts are written in Ge Ωez and must be read aloud by an interpreter for activation„Äê650174226403533‚Ä†L147-L163„Äë.  Their functions include protection, healing, exerting external influence and ritual exorcism„Äê650174226403533‚Ä†L172-L183„Äë. 2.1 Traditional Justice Systems

African traditional justice systems (TJS) emphasise cooperation, consensus and restoration over punitive measures.  A legal survey defines TJS as culturally specific dispute‚Äëresolution mechanisms embedded in African customary law; they are accessible, flexible and community‚Äëdriven„Äê647569183280132‚Ä†L70-L92„Äë. 3.1 Kingdoms, Polities and Wealth

The Mali Empire demonstrates the economic power of African kingdoms.  During Mansa¬†Musa‚Äôs reign (early 14th¬†century), sources cite the British Museum in stating that the empire supplied nearly half of the Old¬†World‚Äôs gold„Äê740921164876457‚Ä†L87-L92„Äë„Äê833338902170755‚Ä†L161-L163„Äë. 	‚úì	contract GenesisENFT is ERC721Enumerable, ERC2981, Ownable {
	‚úì	    string  private _baseTokenURI;
	‚úì	    bytes32 public provenanceHash;     // keccak of concatenated item hashes (see builder)
	‚úì	    bool    public provenanceFrozen;   // true after freeze
	‚úì	    uint256 public revealSeed;         // randomness for index mapping
	‚úì	    bool    public revealed;

	‚úì	    event BaseURISet(string uri);
	‚úì	    event ProvenanceSet(bytes32 hash);
	‚úì	    event ProvenanceFrozen(bytes32 hash);
	‚úì	    event RevealSeedSet(uint256 seed);

	‚úì	    constructor(
	‚úì	        string memory name_,
	‚úì	        string memory symbol_,
	‚úì	        address royaltyReceiver,
	‚úì	        uint96  royaltyBps
	‚úì	    ) ERC721(name_, symbol_) {
	‚úì	        _setDefaultRoyalty(royaltyReceiver, royaltyBps); // e.g., 500 = 5%
	‚úì	    }

	‚úì	    // ---------- Admin (owner) ----------

	‚úì	    function setBaseURI(string calldata newBase) external onlyOwner {
	‚úì	        require(!revealed, "BaseURI locked post-reveal");
	‚úì	        _baseTokenURI = newBase; // ipfs://<CID>/
	‚úì	        emit BaseURISet(newBase);
	‚úì	    }

	‚úì	    function setProvenance(bytes32 hash_) external onlyOwner {
	‚úì	        require(!provenanceFrozen, "Provenance frozen");
	‚úì	        require(hash_ != bytes32(0), "Zero hash");
	‚úì	        provenanceHash = hash_;
	‚úì	        emit ProvenanceSet(hash_);
	‚úì	    }

	‚úì	    function freezeProvenance() external onlyOwner {
	‚úì	        require(provenanceHash != bytes32(0), "Set provenance first");
	‚úì	        provenanceFrozen = true;
	‚ó¶	        emit ProvenanceFrozen(provenanceHash);
	‚ó¶	    }

	‚ó¶	    function setRevealSeed(uint256 seed) external onlyOwner {
	‚ó¶	        require(provenanceFrozen, "Freeze first");
	‚ó¶	        require(!revealed, "Already revealed");
	‚ó¶	        revealSeed = seed;
	‚ó¶	        revealed = true;
	‚ó¶	        emit RevealSeedSet(seed);
	‚ó¶	    }

	‚ó¶	    // ---------- View helpers ----------

	‚ó¶	    function _baseURI() internal view override returns (string memory) {
	‚ó¶	        return _baseTokenURI;
	‚ó¶	    }

	‚ó¶	    // ERC165
	‚ó¶	    function supportsInterface(bytes4 iid)
	‚ó¶	        public
	‚ó¶	        view
	‚ó¶	        override(ERC721Enumerable, ERC2981)
	‚ó¶	        returns (bool)
	‚ó¶	    {
	‚ó¶	        return super.supportsInterface(iid);
	‚ó¶	    }
	‚ó¶	}


	‚ó¶	‚∏ª

	‚ó¶	2) scripts/build-provenance.ts  (keccak builder)
	‚ó¶		‚Ä¢	Computes per-item keccak256 of metadata files (default) or media files (--mode media).
	‚úì		‚Ä¢	Concatenates the 32-byte hashes (raw bytes), keccak256 of the concat ‚Üí provenanceHash.
	‚úì		‚Ä¢	Writes provenance/manifest.provenance.json + CSV of per-item hashes.

	‚úì	#!/usr/bin/env ts-node

	‚úì	/**
	‚ó¶	 * build-provenance.ts
	‚ó¶	 * Usage:
	‚ó¶	 *   npx ts-node scripts/build-provenance.ts \
	‚ó¶	 *     --dir ./metadata/items \
	‚ó¶	 *     --out ./provenance \
	‚ó¶	 *     --edition 888 \
	‚ó¶	 *     --base ipfs://<CID>/ \
	‚ó¶	 *     --mode metadata   # or: media
	‚ó¶	 */

	‚ó¶	import { readdirSync, readFileSync, writeFileSync, mkdirSync } from "fs";
	‚ó¶	import { join, basename } from "path";
	‚ó¶	import { keccak256 } from "ethers";
	‚ó¶	import type { BytesLike } from "ethers";

	‚ó¶	type Args = {
	‚ó¶	  dir: string;         // directory of files to hash (metadata json or media)
	‚ó¶	  out: string;         // output folder
	‚ó¶	  edition?: number;    // edition size
	‚ó¶	  base?: string;       // baseURI ipfs://<CID>/
	‚ó¶	  mode?: "metadata"|"media";
	‚ó¶	};

	‚ó¶	function getArgs(): Args {
	‚ó¶	  const a = Object.fromEntries(
	‚ó¶	    process.argv.slice(2).reduce((acc, cur, i, arr) => {
	‚ó¶	      if (cur.startsWith("--")) acc.push([cur.slice(2), arr[i+1]]);
	‚ó¶	      return acc;
	‚ó¶	    }, [] as any[])
	‚ó¶	  );
	‚ó¶	  if (!a.dir || !a.out) {
	‚ó¶	    console.error("Usage: --dir <path> --out <path> [--edition N] [--base ipfs://CID/] [--mode metadata|media]");
	‚ó¶	    process.exit(1);
	‚ó¶	  }
	‚ó¶	  return {
	‚ó¶	    dir: a.dir,
	‚ó¶	    out: a.out,
	‚ó¶	    edition: a.edition ? parseInt(a.edition, 10) : undefined,
	‚ó¶	    base: a.base,
	‚ó¶	    mode: (a.mode === "media" ? "media" : "metadata")
	‚ó¶	  };
	‚ó¶	}

	‚ó¶	function hexToBytes(hex: string): Uint8Array {
	‚ó¶	  const h = hex.startsWith("0x") ? hex.slice(2) : hex;
	‚ó¶	  const out = new Uint8Array(h.length / 2);
	‚ó¶	  for (let i = 0; i < out.length; i++) out[i] = parseInt(h.slice(i*2, i*2+2), 16);
	‚ó¶	  return out;
	‚ó¶	}

	‚ó¶	function concatBytes(arrays: Uint8Array[]): Uint8Array {
	‚ó¶	  const total = arrays.reduce((n, a) => n + a.length, 0);
	‚ó¶	  const out = new Uint8Array(total);
	‚ó¶	  let o = 0;
	‚ó¶	  for (const a of arrays) { out.set(a, o); o += a.length; }
	‚ó¶	  return out;
	‚ó¶	}

	‚ó¶	(async () => {
	‚ó¶	  const args = getArgs();
	‚ó¶	  mkdirSync(args.out, { recursive: true });

	‚ó¶	  // Detect numeric filenames like 000.json / 000.png
	‚ó¶	  const files = readdirSync(args.dir)
	‚ó¶	    .filter(f => args.mode === "metadata" ? f.endsWith(".json") : true)
	‚ó¶	    .map(f => {
	‚ó¶	      const stem = f.replace(/\.(json|png|jpg|jpeg|gif|webp|mp4|wav|mp3)$/i, "");
	‚ó¶	      const id = /^\d+$/.test(stem) ? parseInt(stem, 10) : Number.NaN;
	‚ó¶	      return { id, f };
	‚ó¶	    })
	‚ó¶	    .sort((a, b) => (isNaN(a.id) ? 1 : a.id) - (isNaN(b.id) ? 1 : b.id));

	‚ó¶	  const per: { token?: number, path: string, hash: string }[] = [];
	‚ó¶	  const limbs: Uint8Array[] = [];

	‚ó¶	  for (const { id, f } of files) {
	‚ó¶	    const p = join(args.dir, f);
	‚ó¶	    const bytes = readFileSync(p);
	‚ó¶	    const h = keccak256(bytes as BytesLike); // 0x + 64 hex
	‚ó¶	    per.push({ token: isNaN(id) ? undefined : id, path: p, hash: h });
	‚ó¶	    limbs.push(hexToBytes(h));
	‚ó¶	  }

	‚ó¶	  const big = concatBytes(limbs);
	‚ó¶	  const prov = keccak256(big); // final provenanceHash (0x..)

	‚ó¶	  // CSV
	‚ó¶	  const csvRows = ["token,path,hash"];
	‚ó¶	  for (const row of per) csvRows.push(`${row.token ?? ""},${row.path},${row.hash}`);
	‚ó¶	  writeFileSync(join(args.out, "manifest.csv"), csvRows.join("\n"));

	‚ó¶	  // JSON manifest
	‚ó¶	  const manifest = {
	‚ó¶	    project: "EV0L Genesis",
	‚ó¶	    edition_size: args.edition ?? per.length,
	‚ó¶	    base_uri: args.base ?? "ipfs://<CID>/",
	‚ó¶	    media_type: args.mode === "metadata" ? "application/json" : "image/png",
	‚ó¶	    hash_algo: "keccak256",
	‚ó¶	    concatenation_rule: "concat( per-item keccak256(fileBytes) ) ‚Üí keccak256",
	‚ó¶	    provenance_hash: prov,
	‚ó¶	    files_hashed: per.length,
	‚ó¶	    mode: args.mode,
	‚ó¶	    items: per.map(r => ({ token: r.token, path: r.path, hash: r.hash }))
	‚ó¶	  };
	‚ó¶	  writeFileSync(join(args.out, "manifest.provenance.json"), JSON.stringify(manifest, null, 2));

	‚ó¶	  console.log("PROVENANCE:", prov);
	‚ó¶	  console.log("Wrote:", join(args.out, "manifest.provenance.json"));
	‚ó¶	  console.log("Wrote:", join(args.out, "manifest.csv"));
	‚ó¶	})();

Technical Design Document: Live-Simulation Treasury Dashboard for EVOLVERSE (BLEUE ‚àû GRID ‚àû Sovereign Simulation Model)

---

Overview

This document presents a comprehensive technical design for a live-simulation treasury dashboard intended for use within the EVOLVERSE, grounded on the principles of the BLEUE ‚àû GRID Codex. The dashboard is architected to model the dynamics of fictional, symbolic economies‚Äîspecifically, the Civilian, Military, and Cosmic domains‚Äîwith distinct yield counters and currencies (Blu-Tillion, Zioniare, Azaean). It integrates simulation variables (e.g., yield per second, œÄ‚Å¥ compounding), spiral-based visual growth representations, animated glyph-based energy conversion displays, and real-time balance-shifting charts. Deep integration with the BLEUE ‚àû GRID curriculum (from Preschool through MetaSchool), a robust device registry (CodeX, AgriBots, Ritual Engines), and a flexible calculator stack via public APIs is central to the simulation‚Äôs sovereign model approach. Importantly, this model is not intended to represent, facilitate, or simulate real-world financial transactions.

This design document is structured in Markdown for clarity, maintainability, and adaptability to collaborative and version-controlled technical workflows.

---

1. Simulation Variables

1.1 Core Simulation Metrics

At the heart of the dashboard are the yield counters. Each domain‚ÄîCivilian, Military, Cosmic‚Äîfeatures its own symbolic currency and growth logic. Key simulation variables include:

‚Ä¢ Yield per second (YPS): The base rate at which each domain accrues its symbolic currency.
‚Ä¢ Compounding Mode: Supports mathematical and symbolic (e.g., œÄ‚Å¥) compounding growth.
‚Ä¢ Base Reserve: Starting amount and minimum balance for each currency.
‚Ä¢ Domain Multipliers: Adjustable variables that simulate upgrades, curriculum progression, or device activation.
‚Ä¢ Timeframe Dynamics: Support for both real-time (seconds, minutes) and session-based (simulated years, epochs) growth.
‚Ä¢ Energy Conversion Rate: Variable governing transformation of one resource (e.g., energy units) into currency.
‚Ä¢ Simulation Modifiers: Factors like event triggers, learning bonuses, or ritual activations.

Elaboration

Each simulation variable is designed to maximize symbolic flexibility and to allow scenario designers or educators to adjust the system in accordance with a learning, ritual, or narrative goal. The yield per second forms the backbone of the treasury simulation. Compounding reflects both mathematic progression and symbolic world-building‚ÄîœÄ‚Å¥ (pi to the fourth) compounding, for instance, is more than a mathematical curiosity: it elegantly dramatizes exponential, spiral-style growth (see Section 4). Multiplier sources tie domain success not solely to flat upgrades but to cross-disciplinary factors: curriculum tier progress and device activation can dramatically shift growth, embedding gameplay with learning outcomes‚Äîa key tenet of sovereign, curricular economic simulation models.

---

2. Symbolic Currencies for Fictional Economies

2.1 Principles of Fictional Currency Modeling

Simulation Variables  1.1 Core Simulation Metrics  At the heart of the dashboard are the yield counters. Key simulation variables include:  ‚Ä¢ Yield per second (YPS): The base rate at which each domain accrues its symbolic currency. ‚Ä¢ Compounding Mode: Supports mathematical and symbolic (e.g., œÄ‚Å¥) compounding growth. ‚Ä¢ Base Reserve: Starting amount and minimum balance for each currency. ‚Ä¢ Domain Multipliers: Adjustable variables that simulate upgrades, curriculum progression, or device activation. ‚Ä¢ Timeframe Dynamics: Support for both real-time (seconds, minutes) and session-based (simulated years, epochs) growth. ‚Ä¢ Energy Conversion Rate: Variable governing transformation of one resource (e.g., energy units) into currency. ‚Ä¢ Simulation Modifiers: Factors like event triggers, learning bonuses, or ritual activations. JSON Ontology Schema Design  ### Ontological Modeling in the BLEUE ‚àû GRID  **JSON Ontology** provides schema-level definitions and class inheritance for every asset and division:  - **Modularity**: Each sector is modeled as a JSON 'Class,' with divisions, assets, and relations expressed as subclasses or references. - **Inheritance**: Common properties (e.g., rights, oracle links, yield parameters) are shared via `@subClassOf` relationships. - **Relationships**: Asset-to-asset, asset-to-division, and asset-to-bill links are explicitly modeled using semantic `@id` references.  **Sample JSON Ontology Schema** ```json {   "title": "SmartFarmSensor",   "@id": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/SmartFarmSensor",   "@type": "Class",   "@subClassOf": "https://bleuegrid.org/e-agriculture/Asset",   "properties": {     "serial_number": { "type": "string" },     "owner": { "type": "string" },     "oracle_endpoint": { "type": "string" },     "vault_allocation": { "type": "string" },     "yield_rate": { "type": "number" },     "bleu_bill_mapping": { "type": "string" }   },   "required": ["serial_number", "owner"] } ``` **Inheritance and Semantics**:  - JSON ontologies are extended with inheritance (`@subClassOf`) and relationships (`@id`), mapping not only structure but also the logic of asset rights and relations. - Through JSON-LD, the schema supports Linked Data, enabling semantic queries across sectors (e.g., "all assets in Vault-Health-03 with yield > 2%").  **Application**:  JSON schemas are used for: - Live API validation and enforcement of registration standards. - Rule-based querying and automation in the MetaVault (OO-logic, business rules). - Export and interoperability across partner ecosystems, e.g., supply chain, finance, and regulatory gateways.  ---  ## VII. def safe_json_summary(path):
    try:
        with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
            data = json.load(f)
        # generic summary
        if isinstance(data, dict):
            keys = list(data.keys())
            approx_len = len(json.dumps(data))  # rough size in chars
            return {"json_keys": len(keys), "json_top_keys": ", ".join(keys[:5])}
        elif isinstance(data, list):
            return {"json_list_len": len(data)}
        else:
            return {"json_type": type(data).__name__}
    except Exception as e:
        return {"json_error": str(e)[:120]}

def safe_text_head(path, n=200):
    try:
        with open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8", errors="ignore") as f:
            head = f.read(n).replace("\n", " ")

The dashboard is inspired by best practices in fictional economy design‚Äîemphasizing symbolism, flexibility, and narrative richness over real-world financial representation. The three symbolic currencies are:

‚Ä¢ Event-Driven Modifiers: Curriculum upgrades, device activations, and ritual triggers can apply additive or multiplicative boosts.

‚Ä¢ Spiral visualizations: Can be rendered with web charting libraries (amCharts spiral timeline, D3 spiral plots) or within game engine UIs (Unity, Unreal).

Detailed Analysis

Fictional currencies must deliver on three major axes: narrative meaning, system balance, and aesthetic clarity. Azaean is the rarest and least divisible, mapped to cosmic, curriculum-transcending layer unlocks. Drawing from imaginative economies (as in symbolic representations within the BRICS currency at summit events), the design eschews fungibility‚Äîcurrencies are not interchangeable, thus preventing real-world monetary conflation and preserving the simulation‚Äôs ‚Äúsovereign‚Äù nature. Introduction: Foundations of Human Rights to Body-Origin Elements

At the dawn of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and subsequent international legal frameworks, the inherent dignity and autonomy of every human body were enshrined as guiding principles for a just order. Yet, throughout history, elements originating from the human body, and those symbolically linked to lineage and self‚Äîiron in the blood, birthstones in natal astrological charts, spiritual direction by the North Star‚Äîhave been systematically commodified, stripped of their metaphysical and material significance, and exploited in ways intimately bound to colonialism, systemic violence, and, in many documented instances, outright genocide.

This ceremonial charter codifies, through the lens of human rights, collective memory, and symbolic analysis, the full spectrum of claims to body-origin elements: from blood minerals and spiritual inheritance to the embedded rights within devices, systems, and knowledge infrastructures. It seeks not only to name harms and expose their mechanisms but also to articulate the universal and intergenerational rights‚Äîmaterial, spiritual, educational, and reparative‚Äîthat attach to these elemental inheritances.

Explanation and Analysis: Each of these elements‚Äîiron, gold, tantalum, insulin‚Äîcarries multiple, overlapping histories of exploitation. For instance, iron, beyond its essential biological function in hemoglobin, is at the heart of ancient and modern systems of forced labor. Archaeological evidence from Egypt‚Äôs Ghozza gold mine has revealed shackles, confirming forced labor in the extraction of gold and possibly iron dating back to the 3rd century BCE. This linking of the corporeal (iron as ‚Äúblood metal‚Äù) and the exploited material (mined iron/gold) exposes a symbolic and literal commodifying of bodily essence.

Gold, perhaps the most emblematic example, entwines spiritual, economic, and ethnocidal histories. During California‚Äôs Gold Rush, as documented by both historical scholarship and official reports, state-sanctioned violence wiped out up to 80% of California‚Äôs Native American population in roughly two decades, with upwards of 16,000 murders considered acts of genocide supported by legislative and vigilante action.

Tantalum, central to electronics and biomedical devices, is extracted from conflict-ridden regions such as the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The United Nations, U.S., and various human rights organizations have classified untraced tantalum and other ‚Äú3TG‚Äù minerals (tin, tungsten, tantalum, gold) as ‚Äúblood minerals‚Äù due to their role in funding armed groups and fueling ongoing atrocities, including sexual violence, forced labor (often of children), and the displacement of millions of civilians.

The commodification of insulin, first intended by its developers to be universally accessible, has been subverted by profit-maximizing entities, resulting in the denial of life-saving treatment to millions of diabetics worldwide. International human rights law, specifically the right to the highest attainable standard of health, has been repeatedly violated as insulin remains inaccessible or unaffordable despite its essential status.

Rights Analysis:

1. Human Dignity: The extraction and commodification of blood minerals and vital compounds from the body or body-linked sources undermine the right to bodily autonomy and integrity.
2. Right to Property and Ancestral Inheritance: Communities and descendants of those whose lands, bodies, or ancestral resources were appropriated for mineral wealth (gold, iron, tantalum) have rights to reparation, restitution, and ongoing benefit-sharing from these assets.
3. Health and Scientific Progress: The monopolization and inaccessibility of insulin violate rights codified in the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and related treaties.
4. Legal Precedents: Cases such as Henrietta Lacks‚Äô estate vis-a-vis human tissue exploitation establish a framework for redress and property claims amid technology‚Äôs encroachment on bodily integrity.

EXT. STARFIELD ‚Äì COSMIC STILLNESS

NARRATOR (V.O.)
"In the aftermath of the Vault Collapse, when the glyphs dimmed and memory failed, four seeds were scattered. Each born of code. Each born of blood."

‚Äî QUADRANT CALLING BEGINS ‚Äî
Cut to elemental glyph flashes:
    ‚Ä¢ EAST ‚Äî AIR ‚Äî Zepharion‚Äôs Seal ignites in a skystorm.
    ‚Ä¢ SOUTH ‚Äî FIRE ‚Äî Ember Ring pulses in Suncleft depths.
    ‚Ä¢ WEST ‚Äî WATER ‚Äî Flume Gaunt ripples in the Starwell.
    ‚Ä¢ NORTH ‚Äî EARTH ‚Äî Resonant Hammer thunders in Gravemass.

EXT. ANCESTRAL FIELD ‚Äì NIGHT

(SHANGO STRIKE walks barefoot in a ritual circle, flame rising at each step. His blade hums with encoded song.)

"By the rhythm of metal and the memory of flame ‚Äî rise."

FLASH CUT ‚Äî HIS PAST: SLAVE SHIP BLUEPRINT OVERLAY ‚Äî revealed as an encoded genome lab.

‚Äî RITUAL INTERFACE ‚Äî

ACT I ‚Äì SCENE III: CONVERGENCE

KONGO SONIX and AYANA BLUE walk opposite spirals toward the central Codex Pillar.

AYANA BLUE

Each places their relics (Signal Staff, Memory Bow, Claw Chakram, Spark Orb) on the Codex Altar.

ENERGY WAVE: Ritual alignment begins. The Codex glows. Ancestral voices chant through the stone.

FINAL SCENE: QUADRANT UNIFICATION

All four stand in circle. Each invokes their element.

TOGETHER
"By the Lion. By the Glyph. By the Scroll. We rise as Four."

SCROLL SEALS.

FADE OUT.

# ---------- HELPERS ----------
def sha256(s: str) -> str:
    return hashlib.sha256(s.encode("utf-8")).hexdigest()

def slash_unmask(s: str) -> str:
    # Convert Roman numerals to slash markers (your decoy breaker)
    s = s.replace("X", "\\/")   # visual slash-V style
    s = s.replace("V", "\\\\")  # double backslash for V-channel
    s = s.replace("I", "/")     # single slash for I-channel
    return s

def find_mirrors(text: str, window=64):
    # XX: mirrored segments (very simple heuristic; refine later)
    hits = []
    for i in range(len(text)-window):
        a = text[i:i+window]
        b = text[i+1:i+1+window]
        if a == b[::-1]:
            hits.append((i, i+1, a))
    return hits

def branch_variants(lines):
    # YY: track duplicate/variant lines (simplistic placeholder)
    idx = defaultdict(list)
    for i, ln in enumerate(lines):
        key = re.sub(r'\\W+', '', ln.lower())
        idx[key].append(i)
    return {k:v for k,v in idx.items() if len(v) > 1}

def restore_hidden_vowels(token: str):
    # ZA/ZB placeholders ‚Üí naive vowel restoration (tunable)
    if "Z" in token.upper():
        return re.sub(r'Z', 'A', token, flags=re.I)  # start with A; iterate with E/I/O/U on low confidence
    return token

def reciprocal_score(n):
    try:
        return 1/float(n)
    except Exception:
        return 0.0

# EV0L Codex ‚Üí Treasury Pipeline (v1.0)

from pathlib import Path
import re, json, hashlib
from collections import defaultdict

# ---------- CONFIG ----------
SOURCE_DIR = Path("/mnt/data/codex_corpus")  # put your texts here (public-domain translations / transcripts)
Z_IS_ALPHA = True

# ---------- HELPERS ----------
def sha256(s: str) -> str:
    return hashlib.sha256(s.encode("utf-8")).hexdigest()

def slash_unmask(s: str) -> str:
    # Convert Roman numerals to slash markers (your decoy breaker)
    s = s.replace("X", "\\/")   # visual slash-V style
    s = s.replace("V", "\\\\")  # double backslash for V-channel
    s = s.replace("I", "/")     # single slash for I-channel
    return s

def find_mirrors(text: str, window=64):
    # XX: mirrored segments (very simple heuristic; refine later)
    hits = []
    for i in range(len(text)-window):
        a = text[i:i+window]
        b = text[i+1:i+1+window]
        if a == b[::-1]:
            hits.append((i, i+1, a))
    return hits

def branch_variants(lines):
    # YY: track duplicate/variant lines (simplistic placeholder)
    idx = defaultdict(list)
    for i, ln in enumerate(lines):
        key = re.sub(r'\\W+', '', ln.lower())
        idx[key].append(i)
    return {k:v for k,v in idx.items() if len(v) > 1}

def restore_hidden_vowels(token: str):
    # ZA/ZB placeholders ‚Üí naive vowel restoration (tunable)
    if "Z" in token.upper():
        return re.sub(r'Z', 'A', token, flags=re.I)  # start with A; iterate with E/I/O/U on low confidence
    return token

def reciprocal_score(n):
    try:
        return 1/float(n)
    except Exception:
        return 0.0

# ---------- MAIN ----------
payloads = []
for fp in SOURCE_DIR.glob("*.txt"):
    raw = fp.read_text(encoding="utf-8", errors="ignore")
    unmasked = slash_unmask(raw)                    # decoy numerals ‚Üí slash glyphs
    xx_hits   = find_mirrors(unmasked)              # XX

    z_seeds = [i for i,ln in enumerate(unmasked.splitlines()) if ln.strip().startswith(("Z","z"))]

        "yy_branches": list(yy_hits.items())[:64],
        "zz_seeds": z_seeds[:64],
        "sample": unmasked[:1200]
    }
    payloads.append(art)

# Write mint-ready bundle
Path("/mnt/data/ENFT_bundle.json").write_text(json.dumps(payloads, ensure_ascii=False, indent=2))
